text:
- [Narrator] The outcome
of a football match
can never be predicted.

But what incidents in a game
can help a team to victory?

And how well do players
handle being pressed?

How do they find their way
out from opposition pressure?
Win Probability and pressure handling

are the new Bundesliga
Match Facts powered by AWS.
The outcome of a football match
is and remains unpredictable.
Depending on the course of the game
and its significant events,

the chances of victory are
sometimes better for one team,
sometimes for the other.

The new Bundesliga's
Match Fact Win Probability

derives Win Probabilities
from the associated data

and informs when the
tide seems to be turning.
For this purpose, let's use the game

between Bochum and Werder
Bremen from match day five
of the current season as an example.

An important component for
calculating the Win Probability
is the number and quality of chances,
measured by the expected goals or xGoals.

Up to the 80th minute,
Bochum had 17 shots on goal
inside and outside the penalty area
with a cumulative xGoals value of 1.3.

Werder Bremen had
registered 13 shots on goal

up to this point, coming
to an xGoals value of 0.9.

This shows, based on
the goal scoring chances

and their quality, that the
teams are roughly on a par

with each other and the Win
Probability for both teams
is also level at this point.
But a late goal like this
from Niclas FÃ¼llkrug changes everything.

- [Commentator] Werder
Bremen got the opening goal
of the game.

- [Narrator] His header
raises the probability
of a Bremen win,

also in light of the short
amount of time left to 92%.

However, there are other
factors during a match
that influence the Win Probability.

Take Gladbach versus Mainz on
match day five, for example.

In the first half, Borussia
have the better chances
and appear closer to a win than Mainz,
but the score is nil-nil at the break.
A red card shortly after the restart

then changes the course
of the game completely.

The Win Probabilities
converge for the first time

in the match because Mainz
now have a man advantage.

The subsequent free kick is
converted by Aaron Martin

and tips the scale
completely in Mainz's favor.

- [Commentator] Oh, a free
kick of the highest quality.
- [Narrator] A man down and trailing,

Gladbach's Win Probability
drops abruptly to 11%,

while Mainz's chance of
winning soars to 65%.
Thanks to the Win Probability,

these significant switches can
be visualized for the fans.

Other factors used to
calculate the Win Probability
over the course of a game
include the number of penalties awarded,
the number of corners
and dangerous free kicks taken as part
of the Set Piece Threat
and of course, the minutes played.

On top of that, substitutions
of players with skill
have an impact as well.

The new Bundesliga's
Match Fact powered by AWS

Win Probability shows how
the chances of winning change
depending on the course of the game.
Significant changes in the Win Probability

are made visible by a
corresponding graphic.

It also allows you to pinpoint
which actions in the match
are decisive for its outcome.
(upbeat music)

The new Bundesliga Match
Fact Pressure Handling
shows how often a player can escape
from significant pressure situations
without losing the ball.
There are four ways of doing this:

passing, dribbling,
getting fouled or shooting.
How often a player successfully executes

one of these ways is
shown in the Escape Rate,
the main KPI of Pressure Handling.

Additionally, exceptional
performance that can be delivered
despite the high pressure will be shown
via the offensive dual rate,
the completed pass rate under pressure,
shot efficiency, as well as goals scored.

Above all, creative
players in central midfield

regularly operates between
the lines of the opponents
and are therefore automatically exposed
to high pressure from the opposition.

One player who primarily
escapes pressure situations
by passing is Frankfurt's Mario Gotze.

Here he's put under
pressure on the touchline
by three Koln players

but he keeps a cool head,
looks out for his teammate

and resolves the situation
with a ball over the top.

His Escape Rate up to
match day five was 52%.

That means he'd been able to
retain possession for his team

in every second match
situation so far in the season.
Escaping pressure with few touches
of the ball is an art in itself.
One of the best players in this area

is Buyern's Joshua Kimmich
with his assured passing game.
The Germany international prevails
seven out of 10 pressure situations,
one of the top values in the Bundesliga.
He's often only stoppable through fouls
when in these pressure situations.
Jeremie Frimpong of Bayer Leverkusen
is also often put under pressure

but deals with it in his
own way through dribbling.
Thanks to his pace and mobility,
he often looks to take on the man
and is not put off by being pressed
by several opponents simultaneously.
Thanks to his skill as a sprinter,

he can often only be stopped
in this case by a foul,

which is recorded as a
challenge one for him.

Consequentially, he had a
success rate of 67% in tackles.

The fourth way of escaping
pressure situations is shooting.
Union Berlin forward, Sheraldo Becker,
has been the best in the division at this
after the first five match days.

Against RB Leipzig,
he's put under pressure

in the tightest of
spaces by three opponents

in the penalty box and
is still able to shoot.

Despite the goal probability
being 11%, he scores.

- [Commentator] It's a
masterclass from Union Berlin.
Becker finds the top corner.
- [Narrator] Pressure Handling.

The new Bundesliga's
Match Fact powered by AWS

is impressive in showing
fans how well a player

can escape a pressure situation
without losing the ball.

The higher the Escape Rate,
the better the player deals
with pressure from the opposition.

At the same time, it also
highlights special performances
that the player can deliver.
(crowd cheering in background)
